docs.lead_paragraph: In another effort to distance himself from the Connecticut trash authority's failed deal with Enron Corporation, Gov. John G. Rowland asked nine of the authority's board members yesterday to resign. The Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority lost about $213 million in a murky deal with Enron last year and then, in February, raised municipal dumping fees to make up the loss, outraging taxpayers. Last week, Mr. Rowland, up for re-election in November, dismissed Peter Ellef, his co-chief of staff, who was also the most prominent of the governor's 12 appointees to the trash board. Yesterday, the governor sent out letters demanding that his nine remaining appointees resign by June 30. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)
docs.abstract: Connecticut Gov John Rowland asks nine members of state trash authority to resign following failed deal with Enron Corp in which Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority lost $213 million and then raised municipal dumping fees to recoup loss (S)

docs.snippet: This just in: analysts for big securities firms are bullish about the stocks they cover. Many do not spend enough time on fundamental research. Some face pressure from their investment banking colleagues to maintain positive ratings on companies. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: This just in: analysts for big securities firms are bullish about the stocks they cover. Many do not spend enough time on fundamental research. Some face pressure from their investment banking colleagues to maintain positive ratings on companies. Sometimes the pressure comes from the companies themselves, or even from big shareholders, who would rather not hear bad news. These were among the revelations yesterday at a hearing of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee as lawmakers grilled analysts about their failure to diagnose the rot at Enron before the company's sudden collapse last fall.
docs.abstract: Analysis: Government lawmakers want reform in securities industry on making research better or erasing potential for conflicts within banks and brokerage houses in wake of Enron Corp collapse; analysts testifying at Senate hearing agree that Wall Street analysts are too bullish, but most do not know how to make changes; Sen Robert G Torricelli says status quo is not option; photo (M)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    I hope that Americans will reject William Safire's suggestion (''The Flipped-Over Rock,'' column, Feb. 21) that because both political parties have been tarnished by the Enron and Global Crossing scandals, the country should move...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I hope that Americans will reject William Safire's suggestion (''The Flipped-Over Rock,'' column, Feb. 21) that because both political parties have been tarnished by the Enron and Global Crossing scandals, the country should move on and deal with the corporate governance and accounting issues. The corruption of the political system will be only marginally addressed by the campaign finance reforms before Congress. If the parties will not punish their own for what appears to be blatantly unethical conduct, then we all have a civic duty to scream and vote until the ears of our leaders cannot be purchased. JOSEPH R. HARBESON Yonkers, Feb. 21, 2002
docs.abstract: Joseph R Harbeson letter disputes William Safire's February 21 Op-Ed column on political fallout from Enron scandal

docs.lead_paragraph: SPECIAL purpose vehicles. Credit derivatives. Gain-on-sale treatment. Off-balance sheet financing. Enron may have collapsed, but the market for esoteric accounting is still booming. And that is bad news. Securities markets are all about numbers, from sales and profits to debt outstanding. If investors cannot believe the figures put out by public companies, they will be much less willing to risk their money on stocks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers heard sharply conflicting testimony today from Enron's former chief executive, Jeffrey K. Skilling, who portrayed himself as ignorant of the company's questionable practices, and other executives who said Mr. Skilling received numerous and specific warnings that Enron's off-the-books partnerships were improper. Mr. Skilling's testimony, met by hostile questioning and harsh skepticism from lawmakers, followed a parade of current and former Enron executives who invoked their Fifth Amendment rights against compelled self-incrimination rather than explain the partnerships at the center of the company's collapse in December.
docs.abstract: Lawmakers hear sharply conflicting testimony from Enron's former chief executive Jeffrey K Skilling, who says he knew nothing of company's questionable practices, and other executives who say he got many warnings about Enron's improper off-the-books partnerships; parade of current and former Enron executives appear and invoke their Fifth Amendment rights against compelled self-incrimination rather than explain partnerships at center of company's collapse; refusal to testify by Andrew S Fastow, Enron's former chief financial officer, and three others provides rich tableau of far-reaching consequences of Enron's collapse; Skilling tells openly skeptical lawmakers that on day he left company, Aug 14, he believed company was in strong financial condition; Rep Clifford B Stearns cites conflicting evidence and testimony and accuses Skilling of practicing 'plausible deniability'; photos (M)

docs.snippet: Earl J. Silbert, the former Watergate prosecutor hired to defend Kenneth L. Lay, has already passed the first hurdle in his case: making sure Mr. Lay did not testify before Congress. From now on, Mr. Silbert can focus on what he does best, getting...
docs.lead_paragraph: Earl J. Silbert, the former Watergate prosecutor hired to defend Kenneth L. Lay, has already passed the first hurdle in his case: making sure Mr. Lay did not testify before Congress. From now on, Mr. Silbert can focus on what he does best, getting a white-collar client out of a jam. The Enron case brings Mr. Silbert to a spot at the center of a high-profile scandal and his task now is to keep Mr. Lay -- the former chairman and chief executive of Enron who is now an object of national and Congressional scorn -- from being indicted. To do so, he must manage investigations of Mr. Lay by numerous Congressional committees, the Justice Department, the Securities and Exchange Commission, a variety of civil courts and any number of state-level inquiries. Mr. Silbert declined to be interviewed for this article.

docs.lead_paragraph: Before the financial shell games; before Chewco, Raptor and LJM; before the partnerships that earned him $30 million, Andrew S. Fastow had his first setback at the Enron Corporation. The setback came in 1996, when Mr. Fastow, a rising young star in corporate finance, was nearly fired for the poor job he did running a retail unit that aimed to put Enron into competition with local utilities around the country.
docs.abstract: People who knew and worked with Andrew S Fastow, former chief financial officer at Enron, and Enron's internal report on company's downfall portray him as brilliant, ambitious and hard-charging executive who grew obsessed with using complex financing techniques to supercharge Enron's earnings while inflating his own paycheck; friends say Fastow, whose wife is wealthy in her own right, was adamant in his belief that amount of money a person makes is only measure of success in business; crucial question with regard to Fastow is whether he was mastermind behind Enron's most suspect financial deals or, as he has maintained through spokesman, whether he was merely doing, with board's knowledge, the bidding of former chief executives he worked under, Kenneth L Lay and Jeffrey K Skilling; photos (M)
